Anahim Lake Kindergarten and Student Residence

desc: A dormitory for girls has been constructed at Anahim Lake; the dormitory was built by the local Indian band and adjoins the Sistersâ€™ residence.The boys were boarded with other families.

A new dormitory was built at Anahim Lake in the summer of 1963. The Archbishop of Vancouver provided $1000 to the Sisters of Christ the King so they could construct a dormitory for the children of Anahim Lake.
The Sisters of Christ the King met with a contractor to discuss the building of a dormitory at Anahim Lake.
In November, the Williams Lake Agency set aside $400 to move the Anahim Lake dormitory from the old school site to the new site.

In December, the Sisters of Christ the King approached the Education Services office about the dormitory buildings for sale at the radar station in Punzti Lake. The Education Services office agreed to examine the buildings to determine their suitability for use at Anahim Lake.

The Regional Superintendent of Schools recommends building two 25-person capacity dormitories at Anahim Lake which serves as a base for the children on the Anahim Lake Reserve while the parents are away from home; these dormitories would be operated by the Sisters of Christ the King.
In November, the Department agreed to the transfer of the surplus building from the Puntzi Mountain Airforce Base to Anahim Lake to be used as a dormitory.

In March, the surplus building from the Puntzi Mountain Base has not been transferred to Anahim Lake. By May, the building had not been transferred to Anahim Lake. The official turnover of the building was scheduled to take place in June. In November, the new dormitory at Anahim Lake was almost in operation.
The Anahim Lake Dormitory is completed. The building was moved from Puntzi 'last autumn after taking two weeks to tear down, was eight months being re-constructed'.
Staff and students moved into the Anahim Lake Dormitory on approximately April 30th, 1969.
In June, a request for additional funds was made to the Regional Superintendent of Education in order to complete work on the dormitory. Additional funds in the amount of $12 000 are made available.
The Department decided to discontinue the Anahim Lake Indian Day School because the Williams Lake School Board No. 27 had decided to build a new school in Anahim Lake.
The Anahim Lake Indian Day School is closed as of September 1, 1973.
Plans were put in place to turn the dormitory, school, and teacherage over to the Ulkatcho Band.

In May, the District Superintendent of Education proposed the idea of closing the Anahim Lake Dormitory at the end of the 1976-1977 school year. A boarding home program was to be set up for education purposes and was to be administered out of the Williams Lake District Office. However, in August, a decision was reached to operate the Anahim Lake Dormitory for another year; a committee was to be set up to examine the need for the dormitory in the future.

religiousGroups.group: Missionary Sisters of Christ the King

writtenAgreements.desc: An agreement is signed on September 18, 1973 between the School District No. 27 (Williams Lake) and the Department of Indian Affairs and the Ulkatcho Band for use of the two-classroom school at Anahim Lake until construction on the new school is completed.
The Oblate Fathers agree to pay to the Ulkatcho Band $50 per month for rental of the teacherage in 1975.

An Agreement for Transportation is signed between the Department of Indian Affairs and the School District #27 of Williams Lake for transportation of students from the Anahim Lake Dormitory to the Anahim Lake School from September 1, 1975 to June 30, 1976.

An Agreement for Transportation is signed between the Department of Indian Affairs and the School District #27 of Williams Lake for transportation of students from the Anahim Lake Dormitory to the Anahim Lake School from September 1, 1976 to June 30, 1977.

additionalInformation.notes: The living conditions in the dormitory are considered to be better than the homes on the reserve.

Sewage problems have existed at the school since February 1967; the sewage disposal field needs to be completely rebuilt. The sewage problems at the school have contaminated the well water, making it unsuitable for use. The water problems are caused by the large amounts of water and detergents flushed through the septic system by the laundry operations.

In February, the school is closed for a week due to an outbreak of chicken pox and the measles. The Sisters are involved in the nursing since most of the students live in the dormitories.
In March 1968, additional problems with the septic tank are reported by the Sisters to the Cariboo Health Unit. The Sisters state that the septic tank is running off into the river and that the drinking water is beginning to smell and taste foul. A subsequent inspection of the septic tank finds that everything is in working order. A water sample was analyzed and found to be free of contamination.
In January, attendance is low due to an outbreak of the flu.
A health inspection of the dormitory was carried out on November 2, 1978 and the conditions in the dormitory were found to be generally good.

The Department is prepared to make a contribution of $30 per month per pupil for those students whose parents live away from Anahim Lake.
Safety measures and sanitary conditions have to be comparable with those in provincial dormitories.
The Sisters of Christ the King provide meals and clothing for students living in the dormitory.
The students living in the dormitory take their meals in the dining area of the teacherage basement and all meals are cooked on the teacherage stove.
New furniture was purchased for the dormitory.
Construction of the new dormitory had run over budget by 30%; more funds were required to complete the project.
An inspection of the fire safety equipment was conducted at the Anahim Lake School for the Department of Indian Affairs.
In September, an on the job training program had been started at the dormitory.
In July, the budget for the dormitory for the fiscal year 1977-78 had been approved by the Department.
